mark_scheme: Benefits: replace damaged tissues, treat degenerative diseases, reduce transplant shortages (1 mark)
Potential to cure currently untreatable conditions (1 mark)
Risks: immune rejection, risk of tumours, ethical concerns (1 mark)
Embryonic stem cells raise moral issues (1 mark)
Adult stem cells less versatile (1 mark)
Induced pluripotent stem cells reduce ethical concerns but may have instability (1 mark)

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Describe the sequence of events in the cell cycle and explain the significance of each stage. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: G1: cell growth, organelle replication (1 mark)
S: DNA replication (1 mark)
G2: preparation for mitosis (1 mark)
M phase: mitosis divides nucleus (1 mark)
Cytokinesis: cytoplasm division (1 mark)
Significance: ensures genetic continuity and cell viability (1 mark)

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Discuss the adaptations of xylem, phloem, and guard cells in relation to their functions. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Xylem: lignified walls, hollow tubes → water transport/support (1 mark)
Phloem: sieve tubes with pores, companion cells → translocation of sugars (1 mark)
Guard cells: uneven thickening of walls, turgor changes → open/close stomata (1 mark)
All are specialised plant cells adapted for transport and regulation (1 mark)

Cell division, cell diversity and cellul.question: Explain the role of meiosis in maintaining chromosome number across generations and promoting genetic diversity. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Reduces diploid to haploid to maintain stable chromosome number after fertilisation (1 mark)
Crossing over creates recombinant chromosomes (1 mark)
Independent assortment produces many combinations (1 mark)
Fertilisation further increases variation (1 mark)
Essential for evolution and adaptation (1 mark)
Maintains genetic stability within species (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Write the overall balanced equation for photosynthesis and name the energy source. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2 (1 mark)
Light energy is the energy source and chlorophyll is required (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: State the specific site of the light-dependent reactions in a chloroplast. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Thylakoid membranes (grana) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: State the site of the Calvin cycle in a chloroplast. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Stroma (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain the primary role of chlorophyll a in photosystems. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Acts at the reaction centre to donate excited electrons (1 mark)
Absorbs mainly red/blue light to initiate photochemistry (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe the relationship between absorption spectra and action spectra in photosynthesis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Absorption spectrum shows wavelengths absorbed by pigments (1 mark)
Action spectrum shows photosynthetic rate vs wavelength (1 mark)
Peaks largely coincide because absorbed light drives photosynthesis (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Define photolysis of water. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Light-driven splitting of water into protons, electrons and oxygen (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Outline the main steps of non-cyclic photophosphorylation. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Light excites electrons in PSII (1 mark)
Electrons pass along an electron transport chain releasing energy (1 mark)
Energy pumps protons into thylakoid lumen creating a gradient (1 mark)
Photolysis of water replaces PSII electrons and releases O2 (1 mark)
Protons flow through ATP synthase to make ATP (chemiosmosis) (1 mark)
Electrons reach PSI, are re-excited and reduce NADP to NADPH (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Summarise cyclic photophosphorylation at PSI. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Light excites electrons in PSI which enter an electron transport chain (1 mark)
Energy from electron flow generates ATP via chemiosmosis (1 mark)
Electrons return to PSI; no NADPH or O2 is produced (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain chemiosmosis in the light-dependent reactions. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Electron transport drives proton pumping into the thylakoid lumen (1 mark)
Proton gradient produces a proton motive force across the membrane (1 mark)
Protons flow through ATP synthase, catalysing ATP formation (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Name the two immediate products of the light-dependent reactions that are used in the Calvin cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP (1 mark)
Reduced NADP (NADPH) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: State the roles of ATP and NADPH in the Calvin cycle. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: ATP provides energy/phosphorylation for reduction reactions (1 mark)
NADPH provides reducing power (hydrogen/electrons) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Outline the stages of the Calvin cycle from CO2 fixation to RuBP regeneration. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: CO2 combines with RuBP catalysed by RuBisCO (1 mark)
Unstable 6-carbon intermediate forms two GP molecules (1 mark)
GP is reduced to TP using NADPH (1 mark)
ATP provides energy/phosphate for the reduction step (1 mark)
Some TP leaves the cycle to form sugars (1 mark)
Most TP is used (with ATP) to regenerate RuBP (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain the function of the enzyme RuBisCO. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Catalyses the fixation of CO2 to RuBP (carboxylation) (1 mark)
Initiates the Calvin cycle by forming GP (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe two possible fates of triose phosphate (TP). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Used to synthesise hexose sugars/starch/cellulose (1 mark)
Recycled to regenerate RuBP (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: How many turns of the Calvin cycle are required to produce one molecule of glucose and why? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Six turns are required (1 mark)
Because 6 CO2 are needed to provide the carbon for one C6 sugar (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Define a limiting factor in photosynthesis. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A factor that, when in short supply, restricts the rate of photosynthesis (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain how low temperature limits the rate of photosynthesis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enzyme activity in the Calvin cycle decreases (1 mark)
Reduced kinetic energy lowers collision frequency (1 mark)
Slower GP → TP conversion and RuBP regeneration (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe the effect of increasing light intensity on photosynthetic rate when CO2 and temperature are non-limiting. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Rate increases as more ATP and NADPH are generated (1 mark)
Eventually plateaus when another factor becomes limiting (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain how low carbon dioxide concentration affects Calvin cycle intermediates. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Less CO2 fixation reduces GP formation (1 mark)
RuBP accumulates due to reduced carboxylation (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe an investigation to measure the effect of light intensity on photosynthesis using an aquatic plant. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Use Elodea/Cabomba and count oxygen bubbles or measure O2 with a sensor (1 mark)
Vary distance/light intensity with a lamp and light meter (1 mark)
Control temperature and CO2 (e.g., sodium hydrogencarbonate) (1 mark)
Repeat and calculate mean rates at each intensity (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Write the formula used to calculate Rf values in pigment chromatography. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Rf = distance moved by pigment ÷ distance moved by solvent front (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain why different photosynthetic pigments separate during chromatography. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Pigments differ in solubility in the solvent (1 mark)
Pigments differ in affinity to the stationary phase (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain why the action spectrum does not match exactly the absorption spectrum of chlorophyll alone. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Accessory pigments absorb additional wavelengths (1 mark)
Energy is funnelled to reaction centres via antenna complexes (1 mark)
Whole-leaf processes and internal CO2 availability influence overall rate (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe three chloroplast adaptations that maximise photosynthetic efficiency. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Extensive thylakoid membranes increase surface area for light reactions (1 mark)
Stroma contains enzymes and is close to thylakoids for rapid transfer (1 mark)
Own DNA/ribosomes enable rapid synthesis of key proteins (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: State the role of accessory pigments within a photosystem. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Broaden the range of wavelengths absorbed (1 mark)
Transfer excitation energy to chlorophyll a at the reaction centre (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Why is green light least effective at driving photosynthesis in most plants? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Green light is mostly reflected/transmitted, not absorbed (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Define photorespiration and state its effect on photosynthetic efficiency. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: RuBisCO uses O2 instead of CO2 (oxygenation of RuBP) (1 mark)
Produces phosphoglycolate that must be recycled (1 mark)
Wastes energy and reduces net carbon fixation (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain one advantage of the C4 pathway in hot, bright conditions. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: CO2 is concentrated around RuBisCO in bundle sheath cells (1 mark)
Reduces photorespiration at high temperatures (1 mark)
Maintains higher photosynthetic rates under intense light (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Describe how stomatal regulation presents a trade-off for photosynthesis. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Opening stomata increases CO2 uptake (1 mark)
But increases water loss by transpiration (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain how water stress can indirectly reduce photosynthetic rate. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Water stress causes stomata to close (1 mark)
Lower CO2 entry reduces Calvin cycle activity (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Interpret a graph where photosynthetic rate increases with light then plateaus despite further light increase. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Initial rise shows light is limiting (1 mark)
Plateau indicates another factor (CO2 or temperature) is limiting (1 mark)
Further light cannot increase rate without removing the new limitation (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain why ATP synthase is embedded in the thylakoid membrane. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: It uses the trans-thylakoid proton gradient (1 mark)
Provides a channel and catalytic site for ATP formation (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: During illumination, why does the pH of the stroma rise while the thylakoid lumen becomes acidic? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Protons are pumped into the thylakoid lumen and produced by photolysis (1 mark)
Proton removal from stroma increases stromal pH (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain why the Calvin cycle is termed light-independent yet its rate depends on light. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Reactions do not require light directly (1 mark)
But depend on ATP and NADPH generated by the light-dependent reactions (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Why does temperature usually affect the light-independent reactions more than the light-dependent reactions? [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Calvin cycle steps are enzyme-catalysed (temperature sensitive) (1 mark)
Light reactions are driven primarily by photon energy and membranes (less temperature sensitive) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Write a balanced equation for the photolysis of one water molecule. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: H2O → 2H+ + 2e− + ½O2 (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Name two biosynthetic uses of triose phosphate (TP) other than glucose. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Synthesis of glycerol/fatty acids → lipids (1 mark)
Synthesis of amino acids/proteins (using nitrogen) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Name the coenzyme that is reduced in the light-dependent reactions. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: NADP (reduced to NADPH) (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: State the role of the thylakoid electron transport chain. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Transfers electrons between carriers at decreasing energy levels (1 mark)
Releases energy to pump protons for ATP synthesis (1 mark)

Photosynthesis.question: Explain how glycerate-3-phosphate (GP) is converted to triose phosphate (TP). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: GP is reduced using NADPH as a reducing agent (1 mark)
ATP provides energy/phosphorylation for the reduction (1 mark)

Respiration.question: Define cellular respiration. [1 mark]

Respiration.question: State the immediate energy currency of the cell. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: ATP (adenosine triphosphate) (1 mark)

Respiration.question: Where in the cell does glycolysis occur? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Cytosol/cytoplasm (1 mark)

mark_scheme: NAD (reduced to NADH) (1 mark)
FAD (reduced to FADH2) (1 mark)

Respiration.question: Explain what is meant by substrate-level phosphorylation. [2 marks]

Occurs in glycolysis and Krebs cycle (1 mark)

Respiration.question: Describe the fate of pyruvate in aerobic conditions in eukaryotes. [3 marks]

Respiration.question: State the products of the link reaction per pyruvate. [3 marks]

1 CO2 (1 mark)
1 acetyl-CoA (1 mark)

mark_scheme: Highly folded inner membrane (cristae) increases surface area for ETC and ATP synthase (1 mark)
Matrix contains enzymes for link reaction and Krebs cycle (1 mark)
Intermembrane space allows proton accumulation for chemiosmosis (1 mark)

Protons flow through ATP synthase driving ATP synthesis from ADP and Pi (1 mark)

Energy of gradient is released as heat (non-shivering thermogenesis) (1 mark)

Krebs (2 turns): 6 NADH and 2 FADH2 (1 mark)

Glycogen stores become depleted (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Name two plant hormones involved in growth regulation. [2 marks]

Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the role of gibberellins in seed germination. [3 marks]

Enzymes mobilise starch to sugars for embryo growth (1 mark)

Ethene for fruit ripening (or gibberellins for seedless fruit) (1 mark)

mark_scheme: Decreased response to repeated, harmless stimuli (1 mark)

Saves energy and attention for important stimuli (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Compare classical and operant conditioning. [3 marks]

Operant depends on consequences; classical on stimulus pairing (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Name four major brain regions and one function of each. [4 marks]

Choline reuptake; vesicles refilled with ACh (1 mark)

Receptors only on postsynaptic membrane (1 mark)

ATP powers Ca2+ reuptake into SR for relaxation (1 mark)

Different critical day lengths for long/short-day plants (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Describe plant defences against herbivory. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Chemical deterrents (tannins/alkaloids) (1 mark)
Release of volatile organic compounds/pheromones (1 mark)
Physical defences (thorns/trichomes) (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: What is a nastic response? Give one example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Non-directional movement in response to a stimulus (1 mark)
Thigmonasty in Mimosa pudica leaf folding (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Explain how meristems contribute to tropic responses. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Sites of hormone production (e.g. auxin at shoot apex) (1 mark)
Provide dividing/elongating cells to execute curvature (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Outline the withdrawal (flexor) reflex following a painful stimulus. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Nociceptors activate sensory neurons (1 mark)
Interneurons in spinal cord coordinate response (1 mark)
Motor neurons stimulate flexor muscles to withdraw (1 mark)
Reciprocal inhibition of antagonistic extensors (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Explain why the cerebellum is essential for coordinated movement. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Integrates sensory input with motor commands (1 mark)
Adjusts posture, balance and timing (1 mark)
Refines motor patterns for smooth actions (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Define a taxis and give a named invertebrate example. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Directional movement toward/away from a stimulus (1 mark)
Positive phototaxis in moths towards light (or negative phototaxis in woodlice) (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: State two ethical/safety considerations when using woodlice in a choice chamber. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Minimise stress; provide appropriate humidity/temperature (1 mark)
Return organisms to natural habitat after experiment (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Explain the effect of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors at synapses and likely symptoms. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Inhibit ACh breakdown; ACh accumulates in cleft (1 mark)
Prolonged receptor activation causes sustained depolarisation (1 mark)
Symptoms include muscle spasms/paralysis and autonomic disturbances (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the refractory period and its functional importance in neurones. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Period after an AP when Na+ channels inactivate (1 mark)
Limits maximum firing frequency (1 mark)
Ensures unidirectional propagation along axon (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Explain thigmotropism in climbing plants. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Contact stimulus alters auxin distribution (1 mark)
Differential growth around support (1 mark)
Results in twining/coiling for support (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Outline how auxin-mimic herbicides act and why dicots are more affected. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Synthetic auxins cause uncontrolled growth leading to death (1 mark)
Dicots absorb/metabolise these more readily (1 mark)
Monocots show lower sensitivity/metabolism differences (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Describe the role of the medulla oblongata in ventilation control. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Ventilation centres set basic rhythm (1 mark)
Chemoreceptor inputs (pCO2/pH) adjust rate and depth (1 mark)
Sends impulses to intercostal muscles and diaphragm (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Compare neuronal and hormonal communication. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Neuronal: rapid, short-lived, targeted via synapses (1 mark)
Hormonal: slower, longer-lasting, widespread via blood (1 mark)
Different signal types: electrical/chemical vs chemical only (1 mark)

Plant and animal responses.question: Design an investigation to test phototropism in seedlings, including controls. [6 marks]
mark_scheme: Grow identical seedlings in controlled conditions (1 mark)
Treat groups: unilateral light, uniform light, and dark control (1 mark)
Use opaque caps vs transparent caps to test apex role (1 mark)
Measure curvature/angle towards light over time (1 mark)
Control variables: species, age, temperature, water (1 mark)
Replicates and statistical analysis of mean curvature (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Define an endocrine gland. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A ductless gland that secretes hormones directly into the bloodstream (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Distinguish between endocrine and exocrine glands. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Endocrine glands release hormones into the blood (1 mark)
Exocrine glands secrete via ducts onto surfaces/lumens (e.g., enzymes) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: What is a hormone? [1 mark]
mark_scheme: A chemical messenger released by endocrine cells that affects target cells/organs (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain why only certain cells respond to a given hormone. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Target cells have specific receptors for that hormone (1 mark)
Binding triggers intracellular signalling leading to a response (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Compare peptide and steroid hormones in solubility and site of receptor. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Peptide hormones are hydrophilic and bind to membrane receptors (1 mark)
Steroid hormones are hydrophobic and bind intracellular receptors (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe the cAMP second messenger pathway for a peptide hormone. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Hormone binds GPCR on target cell membrane (1 mark)
G protein activates adenylate cyclase (1 mark)
cAMP is produced from ATP and activates protein kinase A (1 mark)
Phosphorylation of enzymes changes cell activity (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Outline how steroid hormones bring about changes in target cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Diffuse through membrane and bind cytosolic/nuclear receptor (1 mark)
Hormone–receptor complex acts as a transcription factor (1 mark)
Alters gene expression and protein synthesis (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Name the zones of the adrenal cortex and one hormone from each. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Zona glomerulosa – aldosterone (mineralocorticoid) (1 mark)
Zona fasciculata – cortisol (glucocorticoid) (1 mark)
Zona reticularis – androgens (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: State two hormones secreted by the adrenal medulla and one shared effect. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Adrenaline (epinephrine) (1 mark)
Noradrenaline (norepinephrine) (1 mark)
Both increase heart rate/prepare body for fight-or-flight (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how adrenaline brings about rapid effects in target tissues. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Binds to GPCR on target cells (1 mark)
Activates cAMP/second messenger cascade (1 mark)
Rapid enzyme phosphorylation changes metabolism (e.g., glycogenolysis) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe the endocrine portion of the pancreas. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Islets of Langerhans scattered in pancreatic tissue (1 mark)
Alpha cells secrete glucagon; beta cells secrete insulin (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Define glycogenesis, glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Glycogenesis: synthesis of glycogen from glucose (1 mark)
Glycogenolysis: breakdown of glycogen to glucose (1 mark)
Gluconeogenesis: synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how insulin lowers blood glucose concentration. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Increases glucose uptake by cells via GLUT insertion (1 mark)
Stimulates glycogenesis in liver/muscle (1 mark)
Increases respiratory use of glucose (1 mark)
Inhibits gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how glucagon raises blood glucose concentration. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Stimulates glycogenolysis in the liver (1 mark)
Promotes gluconeogenesis from amino acids/glycerol (1 mark)
Reduces glucose uptake by liver cells (accept inhibits glycogenesis) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe blood glucose homeostasis after a carbohydrate-rich meal. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Blood glucose rises and beta cells secrete insulin (1 mark)
Cells increase glucose uptake; glycogenesis increases (1 mark)
Glucagon secretion is inhibited (1 mark)
Blood glucose returns to normoglycaemia via negative feedback (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe blood glucose homeostasis during prolonged exercise. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Blood glucose tends to fall; alpha cells secrete glucagon (1 mark)
Glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis increase (1 mark)
Adrenaline supports glucose release in muscle/liver (1 mark)
Insulin secretion decreases to conserve glucose (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Compare Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Type 1: autoimmune destruction of beta cells → absolute insulin deficiency (1 mark)
Type 2: insulin resistance with relative deficiency (1 mark)
Type 1 often early onset; Type 2 often adult/linked to obesity (1 mark)
Management: insulin therapy vs lifestyle/oral hypoglycaemics (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Give two advantages of recombinant human insulin over animal insulin. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Identical to human insulin → fewer immune reactions (1 mark)
Ethical/consistent supply from GM bacteria/yeast (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain the principle of an enzyme-linked glucose biosensor. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucose oxidase catalyses oxidation of glucose (1 mark)
Generates H2O2 or electrons detected electrochemically (1 mark)
Current/voltage proportional to glucose concentration (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Outline the hormonal components of the fight-or-flight response. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Sympathetic stimulation triggers adrenal medulla to release adrenaline (1 mark)
Adrenaline increases heart rate, ventilation and glycogenolysis (1 mark)
Hypothalamus–pituitary–adrenal axis increases cortisol (1 mark)
Cortisol supports gluconeogenesis and stress response (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe negative feedback in the hypothalamus–pituitary–thyroid axis. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Hypothalamus releases TRH; pituitary releases TSH (1 mark)
Thyroid secretes thyroxine (T4)/triiodothyronine (T3) (1 mark)
Rising T3/T4 inhibit TRH/TSH release (negative feedback) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how ADH controls water reabsorption in the kidney. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: ADH released from posterior pituitary when water potential falls (1 mark)
Binds V2 receptors on collecting duct cells (1 mark)
cAMP signalling inserts aquaporin-2 channels into the membrane (1 mark)
More water reabsorbed; urine becomes concentrated (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Define an osmoreceptor and its role in ADH regulation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Hypothalamic neurons that detect blood water potential/osmolality (1 mark)
Stimulate or inhibit ADH release accordingly (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Differentiate endocrine, paracrine and autocrine signalling. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Endocrine: hormones via blood to distant targets (1 mark)
Paracrine: local diffusion to nearby cells (1 mark)
Autocrine: cell signals to itself (same cell type) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain receptor up-regulation and down-regulation. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Up-regulation: increased receptor number/sensitivity with low hormone (1 mark)
Down-regulation: decreased receptors with chronic high hormone (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: State two differences between nervous and hormonal communication. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Nervous is fast and short-lived; hormonal is slower and longer-lasting (1 mark)
Nervous is electrical/chemical via synapses; hormonal is chemical via blood (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe the role of aldosterone in blood pressure control. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Acts on distal tubules/collecting ducts in kidney (1 mark)
Increases Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion (1 mark)
Water follows Na+, increasing blood volume and pressure (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how glucagon uses a second-messenger cascade to activate glycogen phosphorylase. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Glucagon binds hepatic GPCR → activates adenylate cyclase (1 mark)
cAMP activates protein kinase A (1 mark)
PKA activates phosphorylase kinase (1 mark)
Phosphorylase kinase activates glycogen phosphorylase → glycogenolysis (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe two metabolic effects of cortisol. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Stimulates gluconeogenesis/protein catabolism (1 mark)
Mobilises fatty acids for energy and suppresses inflammation (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Give one reason hormone effects can persist after secretion stops. [1 mark]
mark_scheme: Signal amplification/altered gene expression produces long-lasting changes (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain why peptide hormones are stored in vesicles but steroid hormones are not. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Peptides are synthesised and stored for regulated exocytosis (1 mark)
Steroids are lipid-soluble and synthesized on demand, diffusing out immediately (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Outline how thyroxine increases basal metabolic rate. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Enters cells and binds nuclear receptors (1 mark)
Upregulates genes for oxidative metabolism/Na+-K+ pumps (1 mark)
Increases oxygen consumption and heat production (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe one diagnostic test for diabetes mellitus. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Oral glucose tolerance test after overnight fast (1 mark)
Measure fasting glucose, then 2 hours after 75 g glucose (1 mark)
Persistently elevated 2-hour glucose indicates diabetes (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: State two chronic complications of poorly controlled diabetes. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Microvascular damage (retinopathy/nephropathy/neuropathy) (1 mark)
Macrovascular disease (atherosclerosis/CHD/stroke) (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain why hypoglycaemia is dangerous. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Brain depends on glucose; low levels impair CNS function (1 mark)
Can cause confusion, seizures, coma if severe (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe how negative feedback maintains plasma calcium using PTH as an example. [4 marks]
mark_scheme: Low Ca2+ stimulates parathyroid glands to secrete PTH (1 mark)
PTH increases bone resorption and renal Ca2+ reabsorption (1 mark)
Stimulates activation of vitamin D to increase gut Ca2+ absorption (1 mark)
Rising Ca2+ inhibits further PTH release (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Give two design features of hormones that allow signal amplification. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Second messenger cascades activate many downstream enzymes (1 mark)
Each enzyme can catalyse multiple substrate molecules (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how insulin causes GLUT4 translocation in muscle/adipose cells. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Insulin binds tyrosine kinase receptor (1 mark)
Triggers phosphorylation cascade (e.g., PI3K/Akt pathway) (1 mark)
GLUT4 vesicles fuse with membrane to increase glucose uptake (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Suggest why chronic high insulin can lead to insulin resistance. [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Receptor down-regulation or impaired signalling (1 mark)
Post-receptor defects reduce GLUT4 translocation/glucose uptake (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Describe one advantage and one limitation of continuous glucose monitors (CGMs). [2 marks]
mark_scheme: Advantage: real-time trends and alerts improve control (1 mark)
Limitation: interstitial fluid lag/calibration or sensor cost (1 mark)

Hormonal communication.question: Explain how noradrenaline can cause vasoconstriction via α1-adrenergic receptors. [3 marks]
mark_scheme: Binds to α1 GPCR on vascular smooth muscle (1 mark)
Activates IP3/DAG pathway raising intracellular Ca2+ (1 mark)
Increased Ca2+ causes smooth muscle contraction → vasoconstriction (1 mark)
